description: This schema represents a geographic position measurement.

latitude.description: The angular distance of a place north or south of the earth's equator expressed in degrees.

references.description: The NCIT code represents Latitude. Negative numbers indicate South.

longitude.description: The angular distance of a place east or west of the meridian at Greenwich, England, expressed in degrees.

references.description: The NCIT code represents Longitude. Negative numbers indicate West.

elevation.description: The height above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference geoid, a mathematical model of the Earth's sea level as an equipotential gravitational surface.

references.description: The LOINC code represents Altitude (Length:Point in time:^Patient:Quantitative).

The unit of measure of the element. Basic unit is meter (m) [ http://unitsofmeasure.org/ucum.html#para-28 ]. Allowed values are drawn from the SI Length Units and English Length Units Common Synonyms (non-UCUM). The valid UCUM code is different for inch ([in_i]), foot ([ft_i]), yard ([yd_i]) and mile ([mi_i]).

effective_time_frame.description: A geoposition should be associated to a date time time frame.

number_of_satellites_in_view.description: The number of satellites that can potentially be used to determine position.

satellite_signal_strengths.description: Signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) expressed in decibels (dB). The typical value for a good fix is 20-40. The higher the number, the stronger the signal.

references.description: The unit of measure of the element. The bel is seldom used. This is a 'pseudo-unit' because of its standardized definition as being logarithm of a ratio of two measurements with the same kind of quantity.

number_of_satellites_in_fix.description: The number of satellites actually used to determine position.

positioning_system.description: Known systems are listed. Others can be added, if needed. More than one can be used at the same time, hence this is an array
